poem:
"Childhood, Interrupted"

Petite Cléo, tucked in Parisian privilege,
Nanny Gloria, Cape Verde's distant silhouette,
Caught in a dance of love, loss, and vintage regret.
Summer promises with threads of sunlit passage,
Yearns for the tussle of grandmotherly affection.
The world crumbles, yet in brokenness, finds its true direction.
Look - a modest gem, reflecting the hues of human connection.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Àma Gloria review – French coming-of-age drama is a modest gem One of the year’s most hypnotic performances nestles inside this seemingly modest French-language coming-of-age drama. Gifted six-year-old newcomer Louise Mauroy-Panzani is middle-class Parisian Cléo, whose world falls apart when her adored nanny, the titular Gloria (Ilça Moreno Zego, also superb), is forced to return to Cape Verde. Gloria, about to become a grandmother, hits on a compromise: Cléo can visit during the summer holidays". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
